snippet: Retroactive has become the new active in this polluted, convoluted sports era, in which you can too rarely be sure whether the race or game or shot-put contest you just watched was legitimate.
abstract: Christopher Clarey On Track and Field column notes that American Adam Nelson could be awarded 2004 Olympic shot-put gold medal retroactively after Ukraine's Yuriy Bilonog was stripped of gold for doping; asserts that retroactive has become the new active in polluted, convoluted sports era in which one cannot be certain whether any contest is legitimate.
lead_paragraph: Retroactive has become the new active in this polluted, convoluted sports era, in which you can too rarely be sure whether the race or game or shot-put contest you just watched was legitimate.

headline.main: Hard to Call Anyone a Winner, When Medals Are Lost to Doping
headline.print_headline: When a Victory Leaves Us at a Loss
